raw_text:
GM issues 2005 profits warning
 
 General Motors has warned that it expects earnings this year be lower than in 2004.
 
 The world's biggest car maker is grappling with losses in its European business, and weak US sales. GM said higher healthcare costs in North America, and lower profits at its financial services subsidiary would hurt its performance in 2005. GM said it expects to meet its 2004 earnings targets "despite a tough competitive environment".
 
 GM, whose brands include Buick, Cadillac and Chevrolet in the US and Opel, Saab and Vauxhall in Europe, is due to reveal 2004 earnings on 19 January.
 
 It said it would deliver a shareholder payout of $6.0-$6.5 per share this year, as promised, but that next year's earnings per share would be lower, at between $4.0-$5.0. "We're following a roadmap that we believe will deliver strong results," said GM chief executive Rick Waggoner. GM said it was expecting "reduced financial losses" in Europe in 2005. It is in the midst of cutting 12,000 jobs - one fifth of the European total - in a bid to cut costs. The biggest job losses are in Germany. Its vehicle businesses have gained market share in three out of four regions in 2004, achieving record profitability in Asia Pacific and returning to profit in Latin America, the Middle East and Africa. The car maker has diversified into financial services, and is extending the reach of General Motors Acceptance Corp (GMAC), which has said it may enter the home loans market. GMAC has been a strong contributor to profits in 2004 but GM said it will do less well this year, delivering net income of $2.5bn. "Attaining earnings of $10 a share remains GM's goal," the company said, adding it believes it can achieve this in 2007.
llama3.2:1b: General Motors has warned that its profits for 2005 are expected to be lower than in 2004 due to losses in Europe and weak US sales.
The company expects higher healthcare costs and lower profits at its financial services subsidiary to hurt performance.

Despite this, GM plans to meet its 2004 earnings targets, including a shareholder payout of $6-$6.5 per share, but next year's earnings per share will be lower due to reduced financial losses in Europe.
llama3.2:3b: General Motors has warned that it expects lower earnings in 2005 due to losses in its European business and weak US sales.
The company plans to cut costs by cutting 12,000 jobs in Europe and deliver a shareholder payout of $6.0-$6.5 per share this year.
Next year's earnings per share are expected to be between $4.0-$5.0, with GM aiming to attain earnings of $10 a share in 2007.
gemma2:2b: General Motors expects lower profits in 2005 due to challenges in Europe and the US.
They face higher healthcare costs in North America and lower profits from financial services.
Despite these issues, they plan to maintain a shareholder payout of $6-$6.5 per share and aim for earnings per share of $4-$5 in 2006.
While European losses are expected to shrink, GM is cutting jobs and expanding into financial services with GMAC as a key contributor to profits.
Their goal remains $10 earnings per share by 2007.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The world's largest car manufacturer, General Motors (GM), released a report warning about its 2004 earnings.
The report stated that it expected higher healthcare costs and lower profits from its financial services subsidiary to impact its performance in 2005.
GM said it would deliver a $6.
5 per share payout this year, but that next year's earnings per share would be lower, at between $4.
"We're following a roadmap that we believe will deliver strong results," GM chief executive Rick Waggoner said.
GM expects to deliver a lower profit for Europe in 2005 due to job losses and reduced financial losses.
qwen2.5:1.5b: General Motors issues profit warning for 2005, expecting lower earnings due to healthcare costs and financial services losses despite meeting previous earnings targets.
The automaker plans to pay shareholders $6-$6.5 per share but projects lower EPS next year with reduced European financial losses.
Job cuts are part of cost reduction efforts in Europe while diversifying into financial services.
qwen2.5:3b: GM warns of lower 2005 profits due to losses in Europe and US sales weakness.
Higher healthcare costs and financial services issues will impact performance.
Despite tough competition, GM aims to meet its 2004 earnings targets.
The company is cutting 12,000 jobs (one-fifth European total), focusing on cost reduction.
In vehicle businesses, market share has increased in three out of four regions with record profitability in Asia Pacific and profit return in Latin America, the Middle East, and Africa.
GMAC’s contribution to profits is expected to decline this year, aiming for $10 per share earnings by 2007.
opencoder:1.5b: GM issues a series of warnings highlighting potential shortfalls in its earnings and performance, highlighting the anticipated shifts in financial expectations, identified market trends, and new opportunities for growth and development.
The primary concern is the impending decline in earnings, which is expected to be driven by losses from major events like World War II.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: GM expects earnings for 2005 to fall short of 2004 levels due to European losses, weaker US sales, increased healthcare costs in North America, and decreased profits at its financial services subsidiary.
GM will report 2004 earnings on January 19.
Next year's EPS will be between $4.0–$5.0 per share, down from this year's $6.0–$6.5.
GM aims to meet its target despite a tough competitive environment and diversify into financial services through General Motors Acceptance Corp (GMAC).
The car maker expects reduced financial losses in Europe but has achieved strong results in Asia Pacific and Latin America.
12,000 jobs were cut, with Germany accounting for the largest loss at approximately 900 jobs.
GM's vehicle businesses have strong market shares across multiple regions, including record profitability in Asia-Pacific and profits in Latin America.
tinyllama:1.1b: GM has warned that its financial performance will be lower than in 2004 due to losses in its European business and lower earnings at its financial services subsidiary.

The car manufacturer is expected to deliver a shareholder payout of between $6.0-$6.5 per share this year, as promised, while next year's earnings per share are expected to be lower, ranging from $4.0-$5.0.
GM has reduced its financial losses in Europe in 2005 and is in the midst of cutting jobs, including 12,000 employees worldwide.
The car manufacturer hopes to achieve higher profitability in 2007 but has set a target for net income of $10 a share by then.
Despite these challenges, GM believes it can make its target earnings within the year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: General Motors has warned that it expects its full-year profits to be lower than in 2004.
The car maker is grappling with losses in its European business and weaker sales in the US.
The company's financial results for 2005 are expected to be reported on January 19, and analysts expect it to deliver a lower-than-anticipated earnings per share.
This is despite GM promising to meet its previous earnings targets in spite of the tough competition environment.
The company has announced plans to cut 12,000 jobs across Europe as part of its cost reduction efforts.
Overall, GM's vehicle businesses have gained market share and achieved record profitability in certain regions.
However, it is facing challenges in its financial services division due to potential losses in the home loans market.
GMAC, General Motors Acceptance Corporation (GMAC), has been a strong contributor to profits for GM but is expected to suffer lower earnings in 2005 compared to previous years.
The company believes it can achieve this goal in 2007.
phi:2.7b: General Motors (GM) expects its earnings for 2005 to be lower than in 2004 due to losses in their European business and weak US sales.
The car maker has announced that they will deliver a shareholder payout of $6-6.5 per share this year, but it is expected that next year's earnings per share will be lower at between $4-5.
GM has also been diversifying into financial services and is considering entering the home loans market.
While GMAC was a strong contributor to profits in 2004, they are expected to do less well in 2005 with net income of $2.5bn.
Despite these setbacks, GM still aims to achieve earnings of $10 per share by 2007.
orca-mini:3b: General Motors, the world's biggest car maker, warned that its 2005 earnings would be lower than those of the previous year due to higher healthcare costs and lower profits at its financial services subsidiary.
The company also expects reduced financial losses in Europe, but it will still deliver a shareholder payout of $6.0-$6.5 per share next year.
GM said it achieved record profitability in Asia Pacific and Latin America while returning to profit in the Middle East and Africa.

However, its vehicle businesses gained market share in three out of four regions in 2004, achieving record profitability in Asia Pacific and Latin America, and returning to profit in the Middle East and Africa.
The company diversified into financial services and is extending the reach of General Motors Acceptance Corp (GMAC), which has said it may enter the home loans market.
GMAC was a strong contributor to profits in 2004 but predicts weaker earnings this year.
Attaining earnings of $10 a share remains its goal, and it believes it can achieve this in 2007.
hermes3:3b: GM expects 2005 profits lower than 2004 due to European losses, US weak sales, and higher healthcare costs.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: General Motors issued a profits warning, predicting lower earnings in 2005 due to losses in Europe and weak US sales.
The company is also facing higher healthcare costs and reduced profits at its financial services subsidiary.
Despite these challenges, GM said it would meet its 2004 earnings targets.
The car maker expects reduced financial losses in Europe in 2005 and is cutting 12,000 jobs as part of cost-saving measures.
GMAC, the financial services arm of General Motors, may also enter the home loans market, although profits from this division are expected to decline in 2005.
GM's long-term goal remains achieving earnings of $10 a share by 2007.
chatgpt-4o-latest: General Motors has warned that its 2005 earnings will be lower than in 2004 due to losses in Europe, weak US sales, rising healthcare costs, and lower profits from its financial services subsidiary.

Despite these challenges, GM expects to meet its 2004 earnings targets and will maintain a shareholder payout of $6.0-$6.5 per share, though 2005 earnings per share are projected to drop to $4.0-$5.0.
The company is cutting 12,000 jobs in Europe, mainly in Germany, to reduce costs.
GM gained market share in most regions in 2004, achieving record profitability in Asia Pacific and returning to profit in Latin America, the Middle East, and Africa.
Its financial arm, GMAC, contributed strongly to 2004 profits but is expected to perform weaker in 2005.
GM aims to reach $10 per share in earnings by 2007.
stablelm2:1.6b: General Motors issued a profit warning for Q5, as losses in its European business and weak US sales affect performance.
Higher healthcare costs in North America and lower profits at financial services subsidiary hinder results.
GM aims to meet Q4 earnings targets despite tough competition.
It will deliver a $6.0-$6.5/share shareholder payout this year but lower EPS next year ($4.0-$5.0).
Reduced financial losses expected in Europe, with plans to cut jobs and diversify into financial services.
granite3.1-dense:2b: General Motors (GM), the world's largest automaker, has issued a profit warning for 2005, predicting earnings will be lower than in 2004 due to losses in Europe and weakened US sales.

Key factors contributing to this expectation include increased healthcare costs in North America, reduced profits at GMAC (GM's financial services subsidiary), and a challenging competitive environment.
Despite these challenges, GM anticipates meeting 2004 earnings targets on schedule.
The company plans to distribute $6.0-$6.5 per share in dividends this year but expects earnings per share to decrease to $4.0-$5.0 in 2005.
European operations, which include brands like Opel and Vauxhall, are expected to see reduced financial losses next year as GM cuts 12,000 jobs, primarily in Germany.
In contrast, vehicle businesses have achieved record profitability in Asia Pacific and returned to profit in several other regions in 2004.
GM has expanded into financial services through GMAC, which has been a significant profit contributor but is projected to perform less well in 2005, generating net income of $2.5 billion.
The company remains committed to reaching earnings of $10 per share by 2007, driven by its strategy for growth and market expansion.
